ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I can draw a killer band diagram.
Broad introduction into basic semiconductor physics and technology

I learned the basic of semiconductors, their characteristics, and the important devices (transistors, diodes, lasers, LEDs, solar cells, MOSFETS, BJTS, etc.) that run today's world. We also went over basic quantum physics and solid state physics.
Covers inception of semiconductor physics to modern day devices. Labs cover measurement of semiconductor device properties.
I gained a lot of knowledge about the physics behind semiconductor operation.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: The content of the course is soooo interesting!! The labs, while they are long and reports can be time consuming, ultimately do cement the concepts learned in class.
weakness: the lecture content could be organized a better. Sometimes we speed through many slides, without actually pausing to understand what's on one slide. Maybe they could be consolidated to only include the information we will actually cover.

The homework problems were largely self-led. While Professor Tang went in-depth on the theory of semiconductor equations in class, I wish he could have led through the homework problems in class and explained how they functioned within the semiconductor or device. I went to almost every TA office hour to work on the problems instead, and even then we sometimes struggled as a group to understand a concept. I also wish we went over how devices are actually made in the lab (i.e. photolithography, epitaxy, etc.)

Strengths are the exams and textbook homeworks. General workload strictly for the lecture portion of class is fair. The biggest weakness are the mandatory labs which are some of the most confusing assignments in the EE major. The lab procedures were written years ago and have not been updated, so students are always left wondering how certain analysis can be performed when the procedure never explained it, nor was it covered in class. It essentially turns into a guessing game to figure out what the TAs actually want in the reports and understanding how to do said analysis. It was frankly baffling how disjointed the class can seem from the lab material and how unhelpful the TAs were, in terms of providing a clear outline for what each report should cover. Ultimately, students end up learning whats happening in class due to the extensive research they are forced to conduct when trying to decipher the lab assignments.

The bottom line is that an entire scientific field worth of advancements in boiled down to uncontextualized factoids, and it is a shame.

While the material is interesting, the course itself is poorly organized. Labs could be scheduled better so that they fall after the relevant content has been covered in class instead of before, leaving students with no idea what the lab is about.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: As an Electrical Engineering major you have to take this class.
Yes, although be prepared to read the textbook as a supplement to lectures in order to learn the content.

Yes. If you are interested in learning about the crystal structures of semiconductors/materials, how they function as devices, and how they are essential to the operation of modern electronics and the world. There will be lots of math and physics involved so be prepared to be challenged.

If you are EE, its required. My condolences. If you are majoring in anything else (say APHY), please do yourself a favor and say away. The only way this class should be offered is if there are only lectures and no assignments at all, because then students won't be forced to apply the net zero knowledge they have gained from lectures.
This class is the very definition of "mid."
